stream_context.summary: Kaze works on the neon-arcade/space casino course (likely Course 15) for the RTYI demo, polishing visuals and programming new interactive objects such as a materialising bridge, warp platforms, and low-gravity zones.

development_findings.summary: Demo build is being finalised; Delfino plaza will be a hidden stage, but there is still no public release date.
development_findings.quote: Is there a release date for the demo? Nope.

development_findings.summary: Performance testing shows worst-case 22–25 FPS; capping to 30 FPS hides most drops.
development_findings.quote: The absolute worst FPS you can get in this level is … 22, 25. I think this is fine.

development_findings.summary: A bridge effect was rebuilt so it now materialises smoothly, changing colour and fading out without crashing.
development_findings.quote: Look at this. It slowly changes colour… Oh my God, that looks so good.

development_findings.summary: Lens-flare intensity bug traced to editing the wrong asset; fixed by correcting file selection.
development_findings.quote: I edited the wrong one. This is unbelievable.

development_findings.summary: Fading-warp transparency was abandoned; Mario now scales into the platform via direct matrix edits to avoid transparency conflicts with new materials.
development_findings.quote: Applying transparency messes with all my components, so we just scale Mario into the ground.

development_findings.summary: Custom collision type adds an under-lighting effect to warp platforms, giving Mario an upward glow.
Low-gravity zones implemented with a simple flag; can be placed anywhere for quick prototyping.
development_findings.quote: It’s as simple as that. And now we can just put them wherever we want.

development_findings.summary: Discovered and reclaimed an extra 1 MB of N64 RAM, giving unexpected head-room.
development_findings.quote: Finding a full megabyte was definitely a nice surprise.

development_findings.summary: Large portions of original Nintendo OS code are being replaced for efficiency; some routines were ‘50 % slower in eight lines’.
development_findings.quote: A lot of this code is complete dog ass.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans an asset-swapped version (≈ 90 % identical) with original characters and revised movement so it can be sold on Steam without Nintendo IP.
development_findings.quote: Along with RTYI, I also release a game that is 90 % the same content, but we replace all the Nintendo IP with our own.

development_findings.summary: He aims to strip all 64-bit instructions, branding the engine tongue-in-cheek as ‘Super Mario 32’.
development_findings.quote: I’m removing all the 64-bit instructions from this game and only using 32-bit ones.

development_findings.summary: Workflow uses Blender + Fast64; Recomp is considered for a simultaneous PC/N64 build with visual upgrades on Steam.
Kaze values public demos for analytics but usually relies on a single trusted tester for iterative feedback.
development_findings.quote: Personally, what I do is send demos of the game just to one person and have them test.

context_findings.summary: Kaze (German) dislikes small-talk greetings like ‘How are you?’ and sees them as forced information exchange.
context_findings.quote: That’s not a greeting, that’s a question… Why does it matter to you how I am?

context_findings.summary: He is surprised by the strong market demand for retro-style N64 games, citing a peer Kickstarter averaging ≈ $250 per backer.
context_findings.quote: The average person is dropping $250 on this? This is insane data.

context_findings.summary: Legal/financial concerns: physical cart impossible without Nintendo rights; Steam asset-swap is explored to avoid infringement.
context_findings.quote: To make a physical cart, I would need the rights to Super Mario 64 first… Maybe next Christmas Nintendo will give them to me.

context_findings.summary: Expresses excitement and occasional frustration during bug-hunting; celebratory tone when fixes succeed.
Mentions balancing family/social life: haircut, in-laws celebration, watching Sonic movie.

biobak.summary: Currently re-working most of Kaze’s placeholder textures; Kaze is deferring final art decisions to him.
biobak.quote: I shouldn’t spend so much time on textures… Biobak is re-working all my stuff anyway.

zeina.summary: Created the patterned carpet texture used in the casino course.
zeina.quote: What do you think of the carpet that Zeina made? Pretty cool, eh?

zeina.summary: Active in chat; subscribed 47 months; juggling baby care while following development.
zeina.quote: The baby’s sleeping with you and working with you. That’s good.

key_stories.title: Bridge That Wouldn’t Appear
key_stories.summary: A newly modelled bridge was invisible in-game due to texture-alpha misreporting and emulator quirks. Kaze tested on multiple emulators, switched to RGBA-16, and finally achieved a stable, animated materialisation.
key_stories.challenge: Bridge textures rendered fully transparent, sometimes crashing the game.
key_stories.process: Debugged in two emulators, altered texture formats, and tweaked scrolling parameters.
key_stories.outcome: Bridge now fades in with colour cycling and functions on real N64 hardware.
key_stories.key_quote: This is what we wanted. Now it’s finally rendering.

key_stories.title: Warp Platform Rethink
key_stories.summary: Standard fading-warp logic clashed with new materials. To keep performance and avoid transparency bugs, Kaze replaced fade-out with a scale-down animation and added under-lighting.
key_stories.challenge: Transparency on Mario’s model broke lighting and materials.
key_stories.process: Disabled transparency flag, animated transformation matrix, created custom light collider.
key_stories.outcome: Warp pads visually dissolve Mario with a neon glow and run efficiently on console.
key_stories.key_quote: We just scale Mario into the ground—much easier than re-enabling transparency.

key_stories.title: The Steam ‘Twin’ Version Idea
key_stories.summary: Kaze considers releasing a commercial variant of RTYI with original art and tweaked movement so it can be sold on Steam while the fan-hack remains free.
key_stories.challenge: Cannot legally sell a game containing Nintendo IP.
key_stories.process: Proposes 90 % content reuse, replacing characters, movement, and remaining Nintendo code; may leverage Recomp for cross-platform builds.
key_stories.outcome: Still hypothetical; gauging community interest before committing.
key_stories.key_quote: What if I also release a game that is 90 % the same content, but we replace all the Nintendo IP with our own?

open_questions.context: Kaze floated the idea of a legally distinct Steam release but provided no concrete plan.
questions: How serious is this plan—have you scoped time and budget?
Which assets/gameplay elements would change beyond character art?
Would the team receive revenue shares or fixed fees?
How would Recomp factor into simultaneous PC/N64 support?

open_questions.context: He said the public demo is ‘soon’ but gave no date and wants to avoid clashing with Robot’s Christmas release.
questions: What milestones remain before the demo can launch?
How many levels/side levels will the demo include?
What feedback mechanisms will be in place?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions Biobak re-working all placeholder textures.
questions: What is the review workflow between Kaze and Biobak?
How are final texture styles and palettes decided?
How does texture memory budgeting influence art choices?

open_questions.context: He unexpectedly freed 1 MB of RAM.
questions: How will the extra space be allocated (audio, textures, code)?

open_questions.context: Little detail on day-to-day interaction among Kaze, Zeina, Biobak, and Badub.
questions: How often does the core team meet or sync?
How are tasks prioritised and tracked?
How do personal relationships (e.g., Kaze & Zeina) influence workflow?
